title: USA TODAY Sports staff picks for Week 8 of the college football season
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Paul Myerberg provides his opinion of the top three programs in the history of college football. USA TODAY

The first half of the college football season is in the books. The second half starts with a variety of Top 25 matchups across the country that will see national title and conference contenders start to make a push or fall back.

The biggest matchup of ranked opponents sees No. 7 Penn State host No. 16 Michigan. The winner establishes itself as the chief contender to Ohio State in the Big Ten East and would still control its destiny toward making the College Football Playoff. It could come down to which quarterback - Sean Clifford or Shea Patterson - plays the best.

There's two big showdowns in the Pac-12. No. 12 Oregon travels to No. 23 Washington with the Ducks hoping to strengthen its hold on the North division race and keep their faith playoff hopes alive. Even with a win, the Huskies need some help after two conference losses, but the first step is winning Saturday.

Oregon wide receiver Jaylon Redd tries to avoid the tackle of Washington defensive back Myles Bryant during their 2018 game at Autzen Stadium. (Photo: Troy Wayrynen, USA TODAY Sports)

In the South division, both No. 14 Utah and No. 17 Arizona State have just one loss in the league and are tied with Southern California and Arizona. The team that prevails in Salt Lake City gets a major boost to its hopes of reaching the conference title game.

CRYSTAL BALL: Predictions for the second half in college football

REPORT CARD: First-half grades for first-year coaches in college football

MIDSEASON AWARDS: Honoring the highs and lows from the first half

And lastly, No. 19 SMU hosts No. 25 Temple in what could be a preview of the American Athletic championship game. The Mustangs are off to the best start in more than three decades, but the Owls have already taken down two teams ranked in the Top 25.
description: Week 8 of the college football season sees major matchups in both the Big 12 and Pac-12 with Penn State hosting Michigan and Oregon at Washington.
